repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
This is a minor regression. Why is performance important for this function?

Similar question for other such cases.

If we can make the faster version support caller-defined validators (while still being fast), that could be interesting.

It's a regression, but not one I think is meaningful. Checking for a list isn't particular valuable, and the functions will _work_ with lists with holes, it'll just behave similarly to how `ipairs` does.

I can add it back if you like, but I think simply checking for `table` is good enough.

For other complex validators, I've left them in.

> For other complex validators, I've left them in.

ok, no objection then.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1012,10 +1010,8 @@ end
 ---                          When omitted, update the global diagnostic options.
 ---@return vim.diagnostic.Opts? : Current diagnostic config if {opts} is omitted.
 function M.config(opts, namespace)
-  vim.validate({
-    opts = { opts, 't', true },
-    namespace = { namespace, 'n', true },
-  })
+  vim.validate('opts', opts, 'tabe', true)

comment_data.body: Is there a written convention around separating the validation of each field into different `vim.validate` calls?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1171,12 +1169,10 @@ function vim.deprecate(name, alternative, version, plugin, backtrace)
     local displayed = vim._truncated_echo_once(msg)
     return displayed and msg or nil
   else
-    vim.validate {
-      name = { name, 'string' },
-      alternative = { alternative, 'string', true },
-      version = { version, 'string', true },
-      plugin = { plugin, 'string', true },
-    }
+    vim.validate('name', name, 'string')

comment_data.body: And if there is, it would be nice for it to be documented :)

comment_data.body:
`:help vim.validate` contains:

```vimhelp
    This function has two valid forms:
    1. vim.validate(name: str, value: any, type: string, optional?: bool)
    2. vim.validate(spec: table)

    Form 1 validates that argument {name} with value {value} has the type
    {type}. {type} must be a value returned by |lua-type()|. If {optional} is
    true, then {value} may be null. This form is significantly faster and
    should be preferred for simple cases.
```

comment_data.body:
I've backtracked on this because of this test failure:

```lua
      matches(
        'expected a list of diagnostics',
        pcall_err(exec_lua, [[vim.diagnostic.set(1, 0, {lnum = 1, col = 2})]])
      )
```

Specifically:
```lua
vim.diagnostic.set(1, 0, {lnum = 1, col = 2}) -- fails
vim.diagnostic.set(1, 0, {{lnum = 1, col = 2}}) -- passes
```

which I think is meaningful enough.
Maybe I’m not englishing correctly but I don’t feel like it’s clear in the main documentation.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
          -- PUC-Lua can only handle string and number for %s in string.format()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -987,6 +988,10 @@ do
 
       ok = (actual == expected) or (v == nil and optional == true)
       if not ok then
+        if not jit and (actual ~= 'string' or actual ~= 'number') then
+          -- PUC-Lua can only handle string an number for %s in string.format()

comment_regular_data.body: reminder that we have a `perf` pr type :) https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/80e37aa533573ef1ad96bcccc006b8d45dc963b9/scripts/lintcommit.lua#L86

> reminder that we have a perf pr type :) 

I actually intended this to be a PR for improved code readability, since it moves away from the less-obvious DSL style and type aliases ('t', 's', 'f', etc). Perf is a bonus 😄.

Fun fact PUC Lua cannot do any of:
```lua
string.format('%s', true)
string.format('%s', {})
string.format('%s', function() end)
```
